title: Isolation of endothelial cells from umbillical vessels
title_html: Isolation of endothelial cells from umbillical vessels

source.description:
• Hank's Balanced Salt Solution (HBSS) (H6648-500ml, Sigma-Aldrich)
  • Enzymatic digestion with Dispase II (29585300, Roche) (2.4 U/ml) in Ham's F12
  • Ham's F12 with 10% fetal calf serum (FCS), penicillin (50 U/ml) and streptomycin (50 µg/ml) for centrifugation
  • Endothelial cell culture medium: MCDB131 (10372-019, Gibco) containing 10% FCS, L-glutamine (10mM), penicillin (50 U/ml), streptomycin (50 µg/ml), epidermal growth factor (0.1 ng/ml), basic fibroblast growth factor (1 ng/ml) and endothelial growth supplement with Heparin (0.4%)

1. umbilical cord is cut at one end (about 1 cm) to identify the arteries and the vein
  2. the vein or artery is then cannulated with a button cannula connected to a three-way stop cock. The cannula is fixed with a cable connector to the cord
  3. The cord is the rinsed with HBSS until the HBSS remains clear and no blood is washed out any longer
  4. Repeat steps 1-3 on the other end
  5. Now both ends are cannulated and the vessel is filled with Dispase II solution
  6. The cord is incubated for
  8. at
  10. Discard the Dispase II solution and replace with Ham's F12 containing 10 % FCS
  11. Carefully massage the cord to loosen the endothelial cells
The cord is incubated for
at
  1. Discard the Dispase II solution and replace with Ham's F12 containing 10 % FCS
  2. Carefully massage the cord to loosen the endothelial cells
Collect the medium in a suitable centrifugation tube and centrifuge for
at 100 x g
Discard the supernatant and resuspend pellet in endothelial cell culture medium and distribute on a fibronectin-coated cell culture dish. Coating with fibronectin should be performed
to
before use. Place the cell culture dish containing your cells in a cell incubator at
in 5% CO2.
After
cells are washed with cell culture medium.
to
after isolation the cells should have formed a confluent cell layer
